## Type Concept

- ### Values:
	- 0 represents logic zero
	- 1 represents logic one
	- x represents unknown logic value
	- z represents high impedance
- ### Strength

	   | Strength | Level Type     | Degree    |
	   | -------- | -------------- | --------- |
	   | Supply   | Driving        | Strongest |
	   | Strong   | Driving        |           |
	   | Pull     | Driving        |           |
	   | Large    | Storage        |           |
	   | Weak     | Storage        |           |
	   | Medium   | Storage        |           |
	   | Small    | Storage        |           |
	   | Highz    | High Impedance | Weakest   |
 - ### Numbers
	- The way we define numbers in verilog is (size)'(base)(number)
		- Size is the number of bits the number is.
			- The way we name the base is as follows:
				- b or B for Binary
				- o or O for Octal
				- d or D for Decimal
				- h or H for Hexadecimal
		- We may use under scores to improve the readabilty.
			- For instance 5'b12345 = 5'b1_2_3_4_5 or 5'b 12_3_45 (and so on)
		- 0, x, z extension.
			- For instance 4'bx1 = xxx1
		- Unsized numbers by default take 32-bits (should be avoided).
		- Example:
			12'o43xz means that 43xz is a 12-bit octal number. It may be expanded as 100 011 xxx zzz (4 = 100, 3 =011 ). It may also be written as 12'o4_3_xz.

     Note - 
     1. The strongest signal prevails.
     2. This data is useful for switch level modelling but not for RTL.

![Signal_Strength_example.png](data:image/png;base64,)

----------------------------------------------------------------------
## Nets and Registers

- Basically we have two data types : Nets, and Registers
- Nets are continuosly driven by a combinational circuit. 
- Wire type is a subset of Net data type, and is commonly used.
- Example: consider the following snippet
```verilog
	wire A, B, Y;
	assign Y = A & B;
```


Here, the tool will by default consider all the variables as Wire type. Also, output is seen only when an event occurs. An event is change in input.
  - **Data types don't define what kind of hardware the design is going to be synthesized into** (the coding style decides this). Therefore, **reg data type doesn't necessary yield hardware registers** even though this data type is said to _hold_ the value.
  - If we wish to hold the input values (so that the output is constantly driven), we may define A and B as reg type variables as shown in the following snippet


```verilog
  reg A, B;
  wire Y;
  assign Y = A & B;
```

  - In the above snippet, Y can be wire as it's been continuosly driven.
  - While assignments, Net type and Reg type can be mixed.
	  - Example: Say a is reg type and b is wire type. Then we can assign a = b or b=a.


 - ### Port Assignments
    - Consider the following statements:
	   - The input to any module is by default net type 'into the module', but could be defined as reg type or net type.
	   - The ouptut of any module is by default net type 'out of the module', but could be defined as reg type or net type.
	   - The inout of any module SHOULD be defined as net type only.


	   ![Port_Assignments.png](data:image/png;base64,)

    - Vectors
	   - A vector is used to represent multiple bits using a single variable.
	   - For example, if we declare ``` reg[3:0] p;``` implies that _p_ is a 4-bit vector with p[3] as MSB and p[0] as LSB.
	   - Consider the following snippet
	   
	 ```verilog
		   reg [3:0] z;
		   wire [1:0] a;
		   wire b, c;
		     b = z[1];
		     c = z[0];
		     
		/Belw are called slices and the range direction must be same as vector/
		 
		     a[1] = z[3];
		     a[0] = z[2]; /we may express a = z[3:2]/
	  ```

   - If we say ```a[0:1] = b[1:0]```, ir means that ```a[0] = b[1]``` and ```a[1] = b[0]```.
   - It is a **good practice to maintain consistency in direction of vector**. The following snippet style is not suggested:
    ``` verilog
    wire [1:0] a;
    reg [0:3] b;
    wire [2:5] c;
	reg [9:7] d;
	      
	```
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Integer Data Types
- Integers store values as signed quantities.
- Suitable for counting, signed number calculation.
- Mostly synthesizeable.
- It basically allocates 32-bits to a variable.
- **Arithmetic operations performed on integer variables produces 2's complement results**.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
## Real Data Types
- Allows decimal and scientific notation.
	- example: 0.125, 1.37, 1.3e-2 etc.,
- If we define a real data variable and assign it to an integer type variable, it would get rounded off.
	- Observe the following snippet:
	```verilog
	real realnum;
	integer intnum;
	realnum = 12.6;
	intnum = realnum;
    ```
	In this case, the intnum would be assigned a value of 13.
- **Real numbers expressed with decimal point should have atleast one digit on either side of the decimal point.**
	- example: .12, 9. etc.,
- This data type is non-synthesizeable. 
------------------------------------------------------------------
## Time Data Type
- For storing and manipulating simulation time quantities.
- Useful for TB implentation
- Non-Synthesizeable.
	- example:
			- Define a variable ' sim_time' by using ```time sim_time```.
			- Call sim_time as ```sim_time = $time```;
- The time variables behave as reg with atleast 64 bits with LSB being 0.
- The time variables are unsigned quantities and unsigned arithmetic operations can be perfomed on them.
------------------------------------------------------------------
## Arrays
- Different types of Arrays:
	- Array for variable types reg, int, time, real, and realtime are possible.
	- Net Arrays
	- The following snippet declares an array of six, one bit registers:
	```verilog
		reg x[0:5];
	```
	- The following snippet declares a two dimensional array of one bit registers. But generally this is not how we declare an array in RTL. This is for simulation purpose:
	```verilog
		reg arrayb [7:0] [0:255];
	```
	- The following snippet declares a two dimensional array of wires:
	```verilog
		wire w_array [7:0][5:0];
	```
	- The following snippet declares an array of 64 integer values:
	```verilog
		integer inta[1:64];
	```
	- **Assigning values to the arrays**:
		- For one dimensional reg arrays:
		```verilog
		reg x[0:5];
		x = 1'b1; //assigns value of 1 to the 3rd element of array
		```
		- For two dimensional reg arrays:
		```verilog
		reg arrayb [7:0][0:255];
		arrayb[1][0] = 0; //assigns 0 to the bit referred by indices [1][0]
		```
	- Note: 
	```verilog
	reg [1:n] a; //n bit register (imagine a horizontal one)
	reg a [1:n]; //array of n, 1 bit registers (imagine a vertical box of n regs)
	```
	
	**Point to remember**: What we define on LHS grows horizontally and what we define on RHS grows vertically.
